hints_html:
Recall the definition of critical point and inflection point. Recall how critical points and inflection points can be found using the graph.

What function do you know which graph has an inflection point? Try to think of at least one example.

What trigonometric function has an inflection point on its graph?
hints_latex:
Recall the definition of critical point and inflection point. Recall how
critical points and inflection points can be found using the graph.

What function do you know which graph has an inflection point? Try to
think of at least one example.
What trigonometric function has an inflection point on its graph?
hints_raw:
Recall the definition of critical point and inflection point. Recall how critical points and inflection points can be found using the graph.
What function do you know which graph has an inflection point? Try to think of at least one example.
What trigonometric function has an inflection point on its graph?
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
This statement is false.

Consider, for example, the graph of \(f(x) = \tan(x)\) for -\(\pi\)/2 < x < \(\pi\)/2. Nowhere do we have \(\displaystyle f'(x) = \sec(x) = 0\), but still the curve switches from concave down to concave up.

The statement is false.

Two more examples are \(f(x)=\sin(x)\), \(0<x<\pi\), and \(f(x)=\cos(x)\), \(-\pi/2<x<\pi/2\). The argument is the same as in solution 1.
sols_latex:
The statement is \textbf{false}.

Two more examples are $f(x)=\sin(x)$, $0<x<\pi$, and $f(x)=\cos(x)$,
$-\pi/2<x<\pi/2$. The argument is the same as in solution 1.
sols_raw:
This statement is '''false'''.

Consider, for example, the graph of <math>f(x) = \tan(x)</math> for -&pi;/2 < ''x'' < &pi;/2. Nowhere do we have <math> \displaystyle f'(x) = \sec(x) = 0 </math>, but still the curve switches from concave down to concave up.

:[[File:Math110 April2013 1b.png|300px]]
The statement is '''false'''.

Two more examples are <math>f(x)=\sin(x)</math>, <math>0<x<\pi</math>, and <math>f(x)=\cos(x)</math>, <math>-\pi/2<x<\pi/2</math>. The argument is the same as in solution 1.
statement_html:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

(b) If \(f\) has no critical points, then \(f\) has no inflection points.
statement_latex:
\emph{Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it
is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a
counterexample.}

\textbf{(b)} If $f$ has no critical points, then $f$ has no inflection
points.
statement_raw:
''Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.''

'''(b)''' If &fnof; has no critical points, then &fnof; has no inflection points.
